Top-3 Scripts:
ul_288644: cd "$HOME/LOREM"
for item in *
do
    test -d "$item" || continue
    mv -f "$HOME/$item" "$HOME/$item.DELETE_ME_LATER" 2>/dev/null
    ln -s "$HOME/LOREM/$item" "$HOME/$item"
done

# Once you are happy that only the correct files have been replaced
# rm "$HOME"/*.DELETE_ME_LATER

ul_74721: cd ~/path/to/dirs || exit 1
find /path/to/dirs -type d -printf %P\\0 | xargs -0 mkdir -p 
find /path/to/dirs -type f -print0 | 
  xargs -0 cp --symbolic-link --parents --target-directory=.

ul_120060: function lnmv
    set dest_dir $argv[1]
    set files $argv[2..-1]

    for f in $files
        set dest $dest_dir/$f
        mv -- $f $dest
        and ln -s -- $dest $f
    end
end

Explanations about Options.-s: make symbolic links instead of hard links

ul_34248: find -L

find . -xtype l

find . -type l ! -exec test -e {} \; -print

find . -type l -exec sh -c 'file -b "$1" | grep -q ^broken' sh {} \; -print

find -L . -type l

ul_107346: find -L -path ~/.wine/dosdevices -prune -o -type f -name 'My Favorite Movie.*' -print

find ~ /mnt/hdd -xtype f -name 'My Favorite Movie.*'

find ~ -type l …

( IFS=$'\n'; set -f;
  find ~ $(find ~ -type l -lname '/mnt/hdd/*') \
       -xtype f -name 'My Favorite Movie.*' )

find -L \( -samefile /exclude/this -o -samefile ~/and/that \) -prune -o \
     -type f -name 'My Favorite Movie.*' -print

Explanations about Options.-samefile:
File refers to the same inode as name. When -L is in effect, this can include
 symbolic links.
Explanations about Options.-lname:
File is a symbolic link whose contents match shell pattern pattern. The
 metacharacters do not treat `/' or `.' specially. If the -L option or the -follow
 option is in effect, this test returns false unless the symbolic link is broken.

Explanations about Options.-s: make symbolic links instead of copying
Explanations about Options.--symbolic-link: make symbolic links instead of copying
Explanations about Options.--target-directory: copy all SOURCE arguments into DIRECTORY
Explanations about Options.-P: never follow symbolic links in SOURCE
Explanations about Options.--parents: use full source file name under DIRECTORY
Explanations about Options.-i: prompt before overwrite (overrides a previous -n option)

ul_6815: Find incoming symlinks
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_288644: cd "$HOME/LOREM"
for item in *
do
    test -d "$item" || continue
    mv -f "$HOME/$item" "$HOME/$item.DELETE_ME_LATER" 2>/dev/null
    ln -s "$HOME/LOREM/$item" "$HOME/$item"
done

# Once you are happy that only the correct files have been replaced
# rm "$HOME"/*.DELETE_ME_LATER

Explanations about Options.-d:
FILE
 FILE exists and is a directory
Explanations about Options.-L: FILE exists and is a symbolic link (same as -h)
Explanations about Options.-t: FD file descriptor FD is opened on a terminal
Explanations about Options.-p:
FILE
 FILE exists and is a named pipe
Explanations about Options.-r:
FILE
 FILE exists and read permission is granted
Explanations about Options.-n:
STRING
 the length of STRING is nonzero

ul_74721: cd ~/path/to/dirs || exit 1
find /path/to/dirs -type d -printf %P\\0 | xargs -0 mkdir -p 
find /path/to/dirs -type f -print0 | 
  xargs -0 cp --symbolic-link --parents --target-directory=.

Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

Explanations about Options.-c: Impose a size limit of n blocks on the size of core dumps.
Explanations about Options.-s:
If used when the shell is invoked, commands are read from standard input. Set
 automatically if the shell is invoked with no arguments.
Explanations about Options.-r:
The shell is a restricted shell. This option can only be used when the shell is
 invoked. See above for a description of what this means.
Explanations about Options.-t:
Impose a time limit of n CPU seconds spent in user mode to be used by each
 process.
Explanations about Options.-p:
The shell is a privileged shell. It is set automatically if, when the shell
 starts, the real UID or GID does not match the effective UID (EUID) or GID
 (EGID), respectively. See above for a description of what this means.
Explanations about Options.-f: Do not expand file name patterns.
Explanations about Options.-i:
Integer attribute. n specifies the base to use when displaying the integer
 (if not specified, the base given in the first assignment is used).
 Parameters with this attribute may be assigned values containing arithmetic
 expressions.
Explanations about Options.-b:
Print job notification messages asynchronously, instead of just before the
 prompt. Only used if job control is enabled (-m).
Explanations about Options.-n:
Do not execute any commands. Useful for checking the syntax of scripts (ignored
 if interactive).

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_120060: Is there a command to move a file, and symlink it back to where it was?
ul_107346: How do I make find follow most, but not all, symbolic links?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_120060: function lnmv
    set dest_dir $argv[1]
    set files $argv[2..-1]

    for f in $files
        set dest $dest_dir/$f
        mv -- $f $dest
        and ln -s -- $dest $f
    end
end
